header.title: The Scroll of Set, Issue Number 155, Volume XXIV-1
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Left-Hand Path, Setianism, Magical Practice

central_thesis: The publication collectively explores the core philosophical and practical tenets of Setianism, emphasizing individual self-transformation (Xeper) through conscious engagement with First Principles, structured magical practice, and a unique ethical framework, all within the context of the Temple of Set's organizational and initiatory structures.

structure_content.chapter_title: [1] First Principles and the Order of Horus
structure_content.summary: This article discusses the central role of understanding 'First Principles' in Setian magic and initiation, particularly within the 'royal' Order of Horus. It outlines 'upward' and 'downward' methods for discerning and manifesting these principles, essential for self-transformation into a divine being, and calls for members to actively engage in this pursuit.

structure_content.chapter_title: [2] New MetaMind Element Open for Business!
structure_content.summary: This piece announces the re-establishment and opening of the MetaMind Element within the Order of the Vampyre, Temple of Set. It describes its purpose as fostering Remanifestation through a Temple-wide working and invites interested Setians to join for general membership.

A detailed, two-part ritual for daily practice is provided, consisting of a 'Morning Ritual' and a 'Final Ritual.' It includes specific steps involving visualization (sphere, personal symbols, Pentagram of Set), invocation of self, reading sacred texts ('Word of Set,' 'Book of Coming Forth by Night'), and projecting impulses for Remanifestation, with the goal of fostering Xeper.

The High Priest reflects on the current year as the 'Year of Cthulhu Rising,' encouraging research into the Pacific and Setian mythos. He elaborates on the magical formula 'Awaken, See, Act,' discusses Lesser Black Magic (LBM) in its various forms (expansive, constrictive, penetrating, encasing) and its ethical implications, and touches upon wealth acquisition and the Temple's role as a 'school' rather than a 'jar'.

This article offers a Setian perspective on death, mourning, and its magical significance. It highlights the non-rational knowledge gained from loss, the awareness of one's own mortality, and the profound personal growth (Xeper) that can arise from confronting death, emphasizing the 'spell' of a life lived without regret.

This article introduces 'The Artisans of Xnum,' a Phyle within the Order of Setne Khamuast, modeled on ancient Egyptian 'working crews' and medieval guilds. It outlines a curriculum focused on Pythagorean, Platonic, Neo-Platonic philosophy, the Hellenistic cult of Agathodaimon, Græco-Egyptian magic, and the quest for Xem, emphasizing 'love of wisdom' and self-transformation (Xeper) through dialectic and the 'Black Flame'.

This piece describes Phyles as initiatory forums within the Order of Setne Khamuast, designed to facilitate self-work and Xeper through 'play' and exploration of Setian symbols and Southern Mysteries. It clarifies their function in aiding individual transformation rather than serving as external authority or collective power.

structure_content.chapter_title: [8] On the Passing of Priest Anton S. Haddad
structure_content.summary: An eulogy for Priest Anton S. Haddad, commemorating his contributions to the Temple of Set as a Knight of the Trapezoid, Vampyre, and Sentinel of the Nephren-Ka Pylon, acknowledging his work in martial arts and his imaginative spirit.

A brief invitation from James Johnson III° for Spanish-speaking members of the Temple of Set to communicate with him, expressing interest in Hispanic culture and language for personal initiative and application.

This article announces the 'Remanifestation' of the Nephilim Pylon into the Midian Pylon, explaining the shift in egregore from the Nephilim (found to be too limited) to the Midian 'Nightbreed' concept. The Midian Pylon offers a haven for 'Nightbreed' (intrinsically isolated individuals) on the Left-Hand Path, focusing on diverse topics for Xeper, while the Nephilim Element continues as a separate metaphorical exploration.

A list of four individuals (Kevin Fordham, Connell Monette, Manuel Weihrauch, K. Lionell Burgess II) who were recognized as Adept II° between December 1997 and January 1998 by various Magisters and Priestess Zeena Schreck.

This article redefines 'karma' from a Setian, Left-Hand Path perspective, rejecting common RHP/New Age interpretations. It presents karma as the principle of cause and effect, emphasizing the universe's reaction to a magician's willed actions and the reciprocal change within the magician, rather than a moralistic reward/punishment system or a justification for status quo.

structure_content.chapter_title: [13] The Council of Nine and the Temple of Set: A Chairman's Perspective
structure_content.summary: This article clarifies the nature and function of the Council of Nine within the Temple of Set. It explains that the Council primarily serves as a corporate oversight board, confirming or denying decisions but not initiating actions, thereby distinguishing its role from the active initiatory work performed by individual Priests and Masters.

structure_content.chapter_title: [14] Preliminary Thoughts on How Reality Works
structure_content.summary: This article explores the intersection of quantum physics, consciousness, and memetics to understand how reality functions and how human consciousness might influence it. It uses concepts like State Vector Collapse, microtubules, and nonlocality to suggest that conscious control over quantum effects is possible, and memetics to explain how ideas propagate and shape perception and reality.

Magus Stephen E. Flowers discusses the Magus's oath of loyalty to the Temple and his resolution to publish annual messages on Runa. He introduces 'maze' (moderation) as a chivalric virtue and a difficult LHP discipline, contrasting it with asceticism/libertinism. The article explores the strengths and weaknesses of the LHP, emphasizing the eternal and impenetrable nature of Runa and the path to individual revelations.

A poetic piece reflecting on eternal change, destiny, and the potential for a 'bastard child' of Orion to rise. It evokes imagery of ancient vows, dormant sleep, and the emergence of new forms from chaos.

A poetic reflection on self-creation and personal growth. The author describes tending a 'grey garden' of experiences, cultivating insights, and consciously shaping one's destiny. It explores the tension between external temptations and the internal imperative to allow one's creations to grow authentically, culminating in a dedicated act of planting a 'single black seed'.

structure_content.chapter_title: [18] On a Magical Diary in Xeper
structure_content.summary: This article advocates for the crucial role of keeping a magical diary in the pursuit of Xeper. It contrasts the 'uninitiated' diary keeper with the 'Black Magician' who uses it as a potent tool for self-knowledge, tracking progress, identifying patterns of will, and solidifying magical goals. The diary serves to organize thoughts, reveal true will, and document the process of 'Coming Into Being'.

This article surveys African magical traditions, specifically divination practices like Ifa and dilogun, and links them to strategy games as 'mathemagical' activities. It introduces a model of initiation ('dimensions' of cultural depth, acquisition context, dialectic) to contextualize cross-cultural magical inquiry, suggesting that elements of these traditions, particularly Remanifestation, can communicate themselves in Setian forms.

structure_content.chapter_title: [20] From the Well of Pythia: The Psychology of a Setian's Possible Entertainment
structure_content.summary: This article offers a Setian-centric review of various musical and film works, connecting them to themes of darkness, self-transformation, and esoteric understanding. It analyzes how different forms of entertainment can resonate with a Setian's psychological and magical development.

This article defines Set as the 'Principle of Isolate Intelligence,' the source of mankind's self-consciousness and individual existence. It outlines core Setian philosophical tenets: Set's dynamic nature, purpose of self-maintenance and expansion, and ethical framework based on individual responsibility rather than worship. It highlights Set's role as a metamodel for autonomous being and the importance of conscious self-development (Xeper).

structure_content.chapter_title: [22] A Noble of Set has Fallen
structure_content.summary: This is a second eulogy for Priest Anton S. Haddad, reaffirming his contributions to the Temple of Set and the community, and reflecting on his enduring presence in the 'Great Darkness' from which all things come.

A poetic exploration of the seeker's journey towards selfhood and an eternal path. It speaks of transcending fear, illusion, and conventional bliss to embrace a willed existence found through reason, experiment, and raw experience, guiding the mind beyond mortal limits.

This comprehensive article by Don Webb V° defines Setian ethics as relativistic and highly individualized, rooted in self-development (Xeper) and antinomianism (avoiding blind obedience). It outlines key ethical goals: increasing freedom, knowledge, opportunity, and environmental beauty. It explains cooperative strivings not as altruism but as identifying with Set's pleasing principles and fostering conditions for collective growth, while clarifying the Temple's apolitical stance in training 'philosopher-kings'.

key_concepts.definition: Individual self-transformation; the process of 'Coming Into Being' and 'Coming Into Being is Established,' central to Setian initiation.

Fundamental, identical essences underlying both subjective and objective universes, making the world knowable and forming the basis for magical manifestation and understanding. They are extracted (Nætic apprehension, Induction, Deduction, Mathematics) and manifested (Four Elements).

The act of manifesting subjective impulses, internalizations, or the essence of something into objective reality. It represents a movement from the subjective to the objective universe, or the re-establishment of a previous form.
A spiritual and magical path emphasizing individual sovereignty, self-deification, challenging external authority and norms, and active engagement with the world to create self-order.

Practical magic focused on manipulating perceptions and social interactions to achieve personal goals. It is categorized into expansive (flaunting rules), constrictive (drawing others into one's rules), penetrating (secret knowledge beyond rules), and encasing (adding new rules to existing sets) modes.

A relativist, individualized ethical code based on rational thought, careful contemplation, and magical understanding. It prioritizes self-development and conscious action to increase freedom, access to knowledge, scope of opportunity, and beauty of environment for both the individual and others, not out of altruism but a recognition that such conditions enable greater Xeper.

A combined concept from Platonic (agathon - guiding principle) and Socratic (daimon - informing principle) traditions, representing the source of one's ethical knowledge and the foundation of ethical behavior, and serving as an 'indwelling' personal guide.

A semi-autonomous initiatory forum within a larger Order (e.g., Order of Setne Khamuast, Order of the Vampyre), designed to facilitate Xeper and self-work for its members, often focused on specific areas of study or practice.
A powerful tool for magicians to track Xeperian progress, identify patterns of will, solidify goals, and gain self-knowledge through regular reflection on experiences, insights, and actions.

A chivalric virtue, meaning 'right measure' or moderation, requiring utmost discipline from a free and sovereign self. It is a difficult Left-Hand Path discipline that involves alternately saying 'no' to some things and 'yes' to others based on individual judgment, rather than external rules.

A field of study positing that ideas ('memes') propagate like viruses in minds, affecting human behavior and perception. It is used to understand how human consciousness and cultural constructs might influence reality and how to strategically 'send dreams' or metacommunication.

The Principle of Isolate Intelligence; dynamic and evolving, whose purpose is self-maintenance, expansion, and perpetuation. Set is not omnipotent or omniscient, but offers the 'Gift of self' (self-consciousness) to mankind, serving as a metamodel for autonomous, individual being.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined across these articles is one of individualized self-transformation (Xeper) through conscious, willed evolution. It encourages practitioners to engage deeply with 'First Principles' of existence and magic, using both intellectual (study of philosophy, memetics) and operative means. Key components include structured initiatory paths within Orders and Phyles (e.g., Order of Horus, Artisans of Xnum), ethical self-governance, and the application of various magical techniques to influence both subjective and objective realities. The system is designed to foster sovereignty, self-knowledge, and the ability to manifest one's unique essence in the world.
tools: Magical Diary (for tracking Xeper, identifying patterns, and solidifying will).
Philosophical study (Pythagorean, Platonic, Neo-Platonic philosophy, Hellenistic cult of Agathodaimon, Græco-Egyptian magic, spiral dynamics, memetics).
Word of Set (for ritual recitation and internal digestion).
Book of Coming Forth by Night (for ritual recitation and immersion).
Visualization and focused intent (for projecting spheres, symbols, impulses).
Self-observation and reflection (for internalizing experiences, understanding 'happenings').
Dialectic and logical reasoning (for increasing clarity and refinement in initiatory process).
Antinomianism (as a method to avoid blind obedience and challenge norms).
Mastery of the 'four elemental grades' and 'three Adepti grades' within the Order of Horus (for command over manifestation and self-mastery of consciousness, will, self).
rituals: Immersion Ritual (Morning Ritual: Projection of sphere, personal symbols, Open Gates, Enter the Rift, Spontaneous invocation of self, Progressive reading of the Word of Set, Projection of impulse; Final Ritual: Projection of sphere, personal symbols, Open gates, Enter the Rift, Final reading of all Parts in successive order, Spontaneous invocation of Set).
Practice of Lesser Black Magic (Expansive, Constrictive, Penetrating, Encasing modes for social and personal manipulation).
Sending Dreams (metacommunication through art, dialogue, illustrative magic).

relevant_quotes.text: The reason that I have dealt with this in such detail is that one way of conceiving of "Understanding" is to say that to understand means that an individual understands the First Principles from which things arise, and therefore understands why they must necessarily be the way they are.

I create this sphere in the name of Nuit, who is the outer and the infinite, and in the name of Set, who is the inner, the finite. By this gesture I utilize the isolated principle of intelligence, seeking always to Become and Come Into Being. Xeper Xepera Xeperu!”
As I have written elsewhere, I was once given a great magical formula for dealing with the world by Magus S. Edred Flowers: “Awaken, See, Act.”
Karma, to a Setian, is how the universe reacts. It is not as simplistic and morally-driven as the "evil for evil and good for good" formula of the RHP magician.
Set is the Principle of Isolate Intelligence. It is dynamic (evolving). Its purpose is self-maintenance, expansion, and perpetuation. This is its only good - otherwise it is beyond good and evil.

critical_analysis.relevance: The Scroll of Set provides an invaluable snapshot of Setian thought and practice in 1998, offering a nuanced understanding of its philosophical underpinnings, ethical considerations, and organizational structure. It positions Setianism firmly within the Left-Hand Path tradition, emphasizing individual Xeper (self-transformation) through a blend of philosophical inquiry, practical magic (including LBM), and structured initiatory orders. The articles demonstrate the intellectual rigor and diverse interests within the Temple of Set, from quantum physics to ancient mythologies, all channeled towards the central goal of conscious self-deification. It serves as a practical guide for aspirants and a historical document for scholars.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of Initiates and advanced practitioners within the Temple of Set, seeking to deepen their understanding of Setian philosophy, ethics, and magical methodology. Secondary audiences include individuals interested in Western Esotericism, Left-Hand Path traditions, Black Magic, modern occultism, and the intersection of spirituality with psychology and philosophy. The document also provides rich material for academic researchers studying new religious movements and contemporary magical practices.
